<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Console_CopyOut:
```c
static int32 OS_Console_CopyOut(OS_console_internal_record_t *console, const char *Str, size_t *NextWritePos)
{
    const char *pmsg;
    size_t      WriteOffset;
    int32       return_code;

    return_code = OS_ERROR;
    pmsg        = Str;
    WriteOffset = *NextWritePos;
    while (true)
    {
        if (*pmsg == 0)
        {
            /* String is complete */
            *NextWritePos = WriteOffset;
            return_code   = OS_SUCCESS;
            break;
        }
        console->BufBase[WriteOffset] = *pmsg;
        WriteOffset                   = WriteOffset + 1;
        if (WriteOffset >= console->BufSize)
        {
            WriteOffset = 0;
        }

        if (WriteOffset == console->ReadPos)
        {
            /* out of space */
            return_code = OS_QUEUE_FULL;
            break;
        }

        ++pmsg;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: All other constructs in the function are standard C and do not in themselves indicate use of a compiler language extension: declarations (const char *, size_t, int32, user-defined types), pointer arithmetic and indexing (pmsg, console->BufBase[WriteOffset]), character literal/zero-termination check (*pmsg == 0), increments (++pmsg, WriteOffset = WriteOffset + 1), conditional statements and breaks, and return statements are ordinary C. The identifier int32 and the type OS_console_internal_record_t appear to be project typedefs rather than compiler language extensions. No compiler-specific tokens (e.g. __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, __extension__, GCC/Clang builtins) or other nonstandard syntax are present elsewhere in the snippet.
